q.content: If (x_n) and (y_n) are Cauchy sequences, then one easy way to prove that (x_n + y_n) is Cauchy is to use the Cauchy Criterion. By Theorem 2.6.4, (x_n) and (y_n) must be convergent, and the Algebraic Limit Theorem then implies (x_n + y_n) is convergent and hence Cauchy.

a.content:
Given an \epsilon > 0, there exists an N such that

|x_n - x_m| < \epsilon \\ |y_n - y_m| < \epsilon for all n > m \geq N.

Let \epsilon_x = x_n - x_m and \epsilon_y = y_n - y_m.

Then

\begin{aligned} & | x_ny_n - x_my_m | \\ & = | (x_m + \epsilon_x)(y_m + \epsilon_y) - x_my_m | \\ & = | x_my_m + \epsilon_xy_m + x_m\epsilon_y + \epsilon_x\epsilon_y - x_my_m| \\ & = | \epsilon_xy_m + x_m\epsilon_y + \epsilon_x\epsilon_y | \\ & \leq | \epsilon_xy_m | + | x_m\epsilon_y | + | \epsilon_x\epsilon_y | \\ \end{aligned}

Since |\epsilon_x| < |\epsilon| and |\epsilon_y| < |\epsilon|

\begin{aligned} & \leq | \epsilon y_m | + | x_m\epsilon | + \epsilon^2 \\ \end{aligned}

Cauchy sequence is bounded. Say bound of (y_n) is Y and (x_n)'s X.

\cdots \\ \begin{aligned} & \leq | \epsilon Y | + | X\epsilon | + |\epsilon^2 | \end{aligned}

The last equation can be any real number. Therefore (x_ny_n) is Cauchy sequence.

q.content: Do the same for the product (x_ny_n).
